content: Well, it appears that the banks packaged all of their credit card debts into securities just as they did with those pesky mortgages. Seeing as there are going to be a lot of CC defaults in the near future, this only adds to the hell we will see in regards to the economy. Let's not forget that mortgage NODs are now at levels much higher than they were during the first wave of foreclosures, meaning that their will be significantly more foreclosures in the second wave that will start late spring and extend into the summer. Let's also not forget that the Commercial Real Estate market is on the verge of taking a nosedive. Well, just add the Credit Cards into that credit crisis. This is not over by any means. In fact, it will get A LOT worse. Hope you have prepared for a complete collapse of our economy. I have. ---http://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/banking/2008-11-09-bank-credit-card-interest-rates_N.htm

title: Why Credit Card rates are rising

content: I know this don't work for everyone....but it's best if you pay your balance each month. Credit is going to get real tight. the economy, in spite of what they tell you, isn't at the bottom yet. Job layoffs continue and houses are still defaulting and the Banks? They aren't lending to folks that actually might need a loan. If you don't need one and have good credit....they'll lend you all you want.

title: Why Credit Card rates are rising

content: If your credit card company sends you notification that your rates are being raised, you have a few options: 1. Accept the rate increase. 2. Pay off the balance and close the account. 3. Decline the rate increase and close the account. It is not necessary for you pay it off in a lump sum, but it IS necessary that you continue to make your payments on time and allow no further charges to be made on that account, including any automatic payments you'd authorized. The issuer is bound by law to honor the original agreement they made with you, but any new charges or late payments can be used as a reason to go ahead and increase the interest rate anyhow.
reply: If your credit card company sends you notification that your rates are being raised, you have a few options: 1. Accept the rate increase. 2. Pay off the balance and close the account. 3. It is not necessary for you pay it off in a lump sum, but it IS necessary that you continue to make your payments on time and allow no further charges to be made on that account, including any automatic payments you'd authorized. The issuer is bound by law to honor the original agreement they made with you, but any new charges or late payments can be used as a reason to go ahead and increase the interest rate anyhow.
title: Why Credit Card rates are rising

content: Very few things should be bought on credit by the average family: Home - on fixed rate loan...preferable through your own bank/credit union, so some of the % comes back to your own accounts. Auto - fixed rate loan - same approach as above.... Major home appliances (Fridge, washer, stove, heater) same approach as above.... Anything else? If ya don't have the cash save up...or you don't need it... Wandering and Wondering

title: Why Credit Card rates are rising

content: I bought one home on credit (30 year fixed, 20% down) and the other I paid cash for. I always pay cash for vehicles, because I see absolutely no reason to pay more for something that becomes so valueless so quickly. The only thing that I use credit cards for is vacations and rentals (for the perks and insurance). I never, ever carry a balance. I believe that the current crisis was the fault of people who just do not get this frame of mind. Thanks. Thanks a lot.
